message_1:
Suppose we have a plaintext message "HELLO" and a randomly generated key "MCKINLEY", both written in uppercase English letters. 

1. Using the one-time pad encryption technique, encrypt the plaintext message using the key. 
2. Write the encrypted message in uppercase English letters.

Note: In one-time pad encryption, each letter of the plaintext message is combined with a corresponding letter of the key using modulo 26 arithmetic.
message_2:
To encrypt the plaintext message "HELLO" using the one-time pad encryption technique with the key "MCKINLEY", we will use modulo 26 arithmetic. We will only use the first 5 letters of the key since the message is 5 letters long.

First, we need to convert the letters to their corresponding numerical values (A=0, B=1, ..., Z=25):

Plaintext message: HELLO -> 7, 4, 11, 11, 14
Key: MCKIN -> 12, 2, 10, 8, 13

Now, we will add the corresponding numerical values of the plaintext message and the key, and then apply modulo 26 arithmetic:

(7+12) mod 26 = 19
(4+2) mod 26 = 6
(11+10) mod 26 = 21
(11+8) mod 26 = 19
(14+13) mod 26 = 1

The encrypted message in numerical values is: 19, 6, 21, 19, 1

Finally, we will convert the numerical values back to uppercase English letters:

Encrypted message: 19, 6, 21, 19, 1 -> TGVSA

So, the encrypted message using the one-time pad encryption technique is "TGVSA".
